protocol.name: CUT&RUN: Targeted in situ genome-wide profiling with high efficiency for low cell numbers
protocol.description:
Cleavage Under Targets and Release Using Nuclease (CUT&RUN) is an epigenomic profiling strategy in which antibody-targeted controlled cleavage by micrococcal nuclease releases specific protein-DNA complexes into the supernatant for paired-end DNA sequencing. As only the targeted fragments enter into solution, and the vast majority of DNA is left behind, CUT&RUN has exceptionally low background levels. CUT&RUN outperforms the most widely used Chromatin Immunoprecipitation (ChIP) protocols in resolution, signal-to-noise, and depth of sequencing required. In contrast to ChIP, CUT&RUN is free of solubility and DNA accessibility artifacts and can be used to profile insoluble chromatin and to detect long-range 3D contacts without cross-linking. Here we present an improved CUT&RUN protocol that does not require isolation of nuclei and provides high-quality data starting with only 100 cells for a histone modification and 1000 cells for a transcription factor. From cells to purified DNA CUT&RUN requires less than a day at the lab bench.
In summary, CUT&RUN has several advantages over ChIP-seq: (1) The method is performed in situ in non-crosslinked cells and does not require chromatin fragmentation or solubilization; (2) The intrinsically low background allows low sequence depth and identification of low signal genomic features invisible to ChIP; (3) The simple procedure can be completed within a day and is suitable for robotic automation; (4) The method can be used with low cell numbers compared to existing methodologies; (5) A simple spike-in strategy can be used for accurate quantitation of protein-DNA interactions. As such, CUT&RUN represents an attractive replacement for ChIPseq, which is one of the most popular methods in biological research.

steps.name: Binding cells to beads
steps.description: Harvest fresh culture(s) at room temperature and count cells. The same protocol can be used for 100 to 250,000 mammalian cells per sample and/or digestion time point.

steps.name: Binding cells to beads
steps.description: Centrifuge 3 min 600 x g at room temperature and withdraw liquid.

steps.name: Binding cells to beads
steps.description: Resuspend in 1.5 ml room temperature Wash buffer by gently pipetting and transfer if necessary to a 2 ml tube. (wash 1/2)

steps.name: Binding cells to beads
steps.description: Centrifuge 3 min 600 x g at room temperature and withdraw liquid. (wash 1/2)

steps.name: Binding cells to beads
steps.description: Again, resuspend in 1.5 ml room temperature Wash buffer by gently pipetting. Centrifuge 3 min 600 x g at room temperature and withdraw liquid. (wash 2/2)

steps.name: Binding cells to beads
steps.description: Resuspend in 1 ml room temperature Wash buffer by gently pipetting.

steps.name: Binding cells to beads
steps.description: While gently vortexing the cells at room temperature, add the bead slurry.

steps.name: Binding cells to beads
steps.description: Rotate 5-10 min at room temperature.

steps.name: Binding cells to beads
steps.description: Divide into aliquots in 1.5-ml tubes, one for each antibody to be used.

steps.name: Bind (primary) antibodies
steps.description: Place on the magnet stand to clear and pull off the liquid.

steps.name: Bind (primary) antibodies
steps.description: Place each tube at a low angle on the vortex mixer set to low (~1100 rpm) and squirt 50 μL of the Antibody buffer (per sample and/or digestion time point) along the side while gently vortexing to allow the solution to dislodge most or all of the beads. Tap to dislodge the remaining beads.

steps.name: Bind (primary) antibodies
steps.description: Place on the tube rotator at 4°C for ~2 hr (or at room temperature for 5-10 min)

steps.name: Bind (primary) antibodies
steps.description: Remove liquid from the cap and side with a quick pulse on a micro-centrifuge.

steps.name: Bind (primary) antibodies
steps.description: Place on the magnet stand to clear (~30 s) and pull off all of the liquid.

steps.name: Bind (primary) antibodies
steps.description: Add 1 ml Dig-wash buffer, mix by inversion, or by gentle pipetting using a 1 ml tip if clumps persist, and remove liquid from the cap and side with a quick pulse on a micro-centrifuge.

steps.name: Bind secondary antibody (as required)
steps.description: Place on the magnet stand to clear and pull off all of the liquid.

steps.name: Bind secondary antibody (as required)
steps.description: Place each tube at a low angle on the vortex mixer set to low (~1100 rpm) and squirt 50 μL of the Dig-wash buffer (per sample and/or digestion time point) along the side while gently vortexing to allow the solution to dislodge most or all of the beads. Tap to dislodge the remaining beads.

steps.name: Bind secondary antibody (as required)
steps.description: Mix in the secondary antibody to a final concentration of 1:100 or to the manufacturer’s recommended concentration for immunofluorescence.

steps.name: Bind secondary antibody (as required)
steps.description: Place on the tube rotator at 4 °C for ~1 hr (or at room temperature for 5-10 min).

steps.name: Bind secondary antibody (as required)
steps.description: Remove liquid from the cap and side with a quick pulse on a micro-centrifuge.

steps.name: Bind secondary antibody (as required)
steps.description: Place on the magnet stand to clear and pull off all of the liquid.

steps.name: Bind secondary antibody (as required)
steps.description: Add 1 ml Dig-Wash buffer, mix by inversion, or by gentle pipetting if clumps persist, and remove liquid from the cap and side with a quick pulse on a micro-centrifuge.

steps.name: Bind Protein A-MNase fusion protein
steps.description: Place on the magnet stand to clear and pull off all of the liquid.

steps.name: Bind Protein A-MNase fusion protein
steps.description: Place each tube at a low angle on the vortex mixer set to low (~1100 rpm) and squirt 50 μL of the Dig-wash buffer (per sample and/or digestion time point) along the side while gently vortexing to allow the solution to dislodge most or all of the beads. Tap to dislodge the remaining beads.

steps.name: Bind Protein A-MNase fusion protein
steps.description: Mix in the pA-MNase to a final concentration of ~700 ng/ml (e.g. 2.5 μL/50 μL of a 1:10 dilution of the 140 μg/ml glycerol stock provided upon request).

steps.name: Bind Protein A-MNase fusion protein
steps.description: Place on the tube rotator at 4 °C for ~1 hr (or at room temperature for 5-10 min).

steps.name: Bind Protein A-MNase fusion protein
steps.description: Remove liquid from the cap and side with a quick pulse on a micro-centrifuge.

steps.name: Bind Protein A-MNase fusion protein
steps.description: Place on the magnet stand to clear and pull off all of the liquid.

steps.name: Bind Protein A-MNase fusion protein
steps.description: Add 1 ml Dig-wash buffer, mix by inversion, or by gentle pipetting if clumps persist, and remove liquid from the cap and side with a quick pulse on a micro-centrifuge.

steps.name: Bind Protein A-MNase fusion protein
steps.description: Repeat Dig-wash steps 28-29.

steps.name: Targeted digestion
steps.description: Place on the magnet stand to clear and pull off all of the liquid.

steps.name: Targeted digestion
steps.description: Place each tube at a low angle on the vortex mixer set to low (~1100 rpm) and add 100 μL of the Dig-wash buffer (per sample and/or digestion time point) along the side while gently vortexing to allow the solution to dislodge most or all of the beads. Tap to dislodge the remaining beads.

steps.name: Targeted digestion
steps.description: Insert tubes into the 1.5 ml wells of a heater block sitting in wet ice to chill down to 0 °C.

steps.name: Targeted digestion
steps.description: Remove each tube from the block, mix in 2 μL 100 mM CaCl2 (diluted 1:10 from a 1 M stock) with gentle vortexing and immediately replace the tube in the 0 °C block.

steps.name: Targeted digestion
steps.description: Incubate at 0 °C for the desired digestion time (default is 30 min).

steps.name: Targeted digestion
steps.description: Add 100 μL 2XSTOP and mix by gentle vortexing. When there are multiple time points, remove 100 μL to 100 μL 2XSTOP and mix by gentle vortexing.

steps.name: Target chromatin release
steps.description: Incubate 10 min 37 °C to release CUT&RUN fragments from the insoluble nuclear chromatin.

steps.name: Target chromatin release
steps.description: Centrifuge 5 min at 4 °C and 16,000 x g and place on magnet stand.

steps.name: Option A: Fast DNA extraction by spin column
steps.description: Place a spin column into a collection tube and add 400 μL Buffer NT1 (from NucleoSpin kit or equivalent).

steps.name: Option A: Fast DNA extraction by spin column
steps.description: Decant the supernatant cleanly from the pellet and transfer to the NT1 in the spin column pipetting gently up and down to mix.

steps.name: Option A: Fast DNA extraction by spin column
steps.description: Centrifuge 30 s at 11,000 x g. Discard flow-through.

steps.name: Option A: Fast DNA extraction by spin column
steps.description: Add 700 μL Buffer NT3. Centrifuge 30 s at 11,000 x g. Discard flow-through.

steps.name: Option A: Fast DNA extraction by spin column
steps.description: Add 700 μL Buffer NT3. Centrifuge 30 s at 11,000 x g. Discard flow-through and replace in rotor.

steps.name: Option A: Fast DNA extraction by spin column
steps.description: Centrifuge for 1 min at 11,000 x g. Let dry 5 min.

steps.name: Option A: Fast DNA extraction by spin column
steps.description: Place in a fresh tube and add 20-40 μL Buffer NE to membrane.

steps.name: Option A: Fast DNA extraction by spin column
steps.description: After 1 min, centrifuge for 1 min at 11,000 x g.

steps.name: Option B: Alternate DNA extraction (preferred for quantitative recovery of ≤80 bp fragments)
steps.description: Decant the supernatant cleanly from the pellet and transfer to a fresh 1.5-ml microcentrifuge tube.

steps.name: Option B: Alternate DNA extraction (preferred for quantitative recovery of ≤80 bp fragments)
steps.description: To each sample add 2 μL 10% SDS (to 0.1%), and 2.5 μL Proteinase K (20 mg/ml). Mix by inversion and incubate 10 min 70 °C.

steps.name: Option B: Alternate DNA extraction (preferred for quantitative recovery of ≤80 bp fragments)
steps.description: Add 300 μL PCI and mix by full-speed vortexing ~2 s.

steps.name: Option B: Alternate DNA extraction (preferred for quantitative recovery of ≤80 bp fragments)
steps.description: Transfer to a phase-lock tube (e.g., Qiagen MaXtract), and centrifuge 5 min room temperature at 16,000 x g.

steps.name: Option B: Alternate DNA extraction (preferred for quantitative recovery of ≤80 bp fragments)
steps.description: Add 300 μL chloroform and invert ~10x to mix.

steps.name: Option B: Alternate DNA extraction (preferred for quantitative recovery of ≤80 bp fragments)
steps.description: Remove liquid by pipetting to a fresh tube containing 2 μL 2 mg/ml glycogen.

steps.name: Option B: Alternate DNA extraction (preferred for quantitative recovery of ≤80 bp fragments)
steps.description: Add 750 μL 100% ethanol and mix by vortexing or tube inversion.

steps.name: Option B: Alternate DNA extraction (preferred for quantitative recovery of ≤80 bp fragments)
steps.description: Chill on ice and centrifuge 10 min at 4 °C 16,000 x g.

steps.name: Option B: Alternate DNA extraction (preferred for quantitative recovery of ≤80 bp fragments)
steps.description: Pour off the liquid and drain on a paper towel.

steps.name: Option B: Alternate DNA extraction (preferred for quantitative recovery of ≤80 bp fragments)
steps.description: Rinse the pellet in 1 ml 100% ethanol and centrifuge 1 min at 4 °C 16,000 x g.

steps.name: Option B: Alternate DNA extraction (preferred for quantitative recovery of ≤80 bp fragments)
steps.description: Carefully pour off the liquid and drain on a paper towel. Air dry.

steps.name: Option B: Alternate DNA extraction (preferred for quantitative recovery of ≤80 bp fragments)
steps.description: When the pellet is dry, dissolve in 25-50 μL 1 mM Tris-HCl pH8 0.1 mM EDTA.

steps.name: Library preparation and sequencing
steps.description: Optional: Quantify 1-2 μL, for example using fluorescence detection with a Qubit instrument.

steps.name: Library preparation and sequencing
steps.description: Optional: Evaluate the presence of cleaved fragments and the size distribution by capillary electrophoresis with fluorescence detection, for example using a Tapestation instrument.

steps.name: Library preparation and sequencing
steps.description: Prepare barcoded libraries for Illumina sequencing with Tru-Seq adapters using a single-tube protocol, following the manufacturer’s instructions. Rapid PCR cycles favor exponential amplification of the desired CUT&RUN fragments over linear amplification of large DNA fragments that are too long for polymerase to complete.

steps.name: Library preparation and sequencing
steps.description: Quantify library yield using dsDNA-specific assay, such as Qubit.

steps.name: Library preparation and sequencing
steps.description: Determine the size distribution of libraries by Agilent 4200 TapeStation analysis.

steps.name: Library preparation and sequencing
steps.description: Perform paired-end Illumina sequencing on the barcoded libraries following the manufacturer’s instructions.

steps.name: Data processing and analysis
steps.description: We align paired-end reads using Bowtie2 version 2.2.5 with options: --local --very-sensitive- local --no-unal --no-mixed --no-discordant --phred33 -I 10 -X 700. For mapping spike-in fragments, we also use the --no-overlap --no-dovetail options to avoid cross-mapping of the experimental genome to that of the spike-in DNA.

steps.name: Data processing and analysis
steps.description: Scripts are available from https://github.com/Henikoff/Cut-and-Run for spike-in calibration and for peak-calling.
